Did you hear about the recently published PISA results 2022 on students' creative thinking? As part of the OECD conference "Learning in a Changing World" on June 18 and 19 in Paris, the OECD's Directorate for Education and Skills, in collaboration with the Yidan Prize Foundation, presented the third volume of the PISA results 2022. In the third volume, the OECD Program for International Student Assessment (PISA) examines for the first time the creative thinking skills of 15-year-old students from 64 countries. The PISA data measure students' skills in four different competency areas: creative writing, visual expression, scientific and social problem solving. The publication shows the differences in performance between different countries, genders, socioeconomic circumstances and school environments. In addition, the PISA results present the strengths and weaknesses of creative thinking and the attitudes of students and teaching staff towards creative thinking. In their speeches at the OECD conference, the head of the Directorate for Education and Skills, Andreas Schleicher, and the founder of the Yidan Prize Foundation, Dr. Charles Chen Yidan, emphasize the importance of creative skills in an age of constant change and innovation. The PISA results on students' creative thinking are intended to help create an evidence base on the state of creative skills in order to develop a support approach for the development of students' creative potential. UNESCO describes Transformative Education as "the teaching and learning geared to motivate and empower happy and healthy learners to take informed decisions and actions at the individual, community and global levels. Learners must engage with the world and find coherence between the world they experience in school and the world we all wish to build outside school." As we continue to actively come up with learning strategies that align with the fast-paced world, we cannot forget to talk about our Kenyan education system as it gradually embraces the competency-based curriculums. It is crucial for institutions of higher learning to consider, evaluate and create new ways for the coming generations to prosper in their own unique worlds. To build these conducive environments for now and our future, we not only need to be highly informed, but also need to learn how to listen, understand, empathize, connect, engage, collaborate, and be active in solving complex problems. Join us in our upcoming Multidisciplinary Conference & Innovation Week (2-5 April) as we delve into Transformative Education and other important sub-themes. Are you interested in thinking about how we can use research well in the education setting? This Discussion Paper from Monash University Mark Rickinson, Lucas Walsh, Jo Gleeson, Blake Cutler and Genevieve Hall examines how using research well can be supported at the system level. Lots of insights and thought provoking points that are drawn from survey, interview and co-design responses from Australian educators and system actors. The paper identifies six system enablers of using research well that cut across three different system levels â€“ actions that support educators as individuals, schools as organisations, and system actors as leaders. This is certainly worth finding time to read.

Complexity as a challenge in teaching sustainable development issues: an exploration of teachersâ€™ beliefs Dorothea Taube Pages: 1-16 | DOI: 10.1080/13504622.2023.2255393 Abstract This article reports the results of an empirical investigation on teachersâ€™ beliefs about teaching and learning and the globalised world as a teaching subject. Following a qualitative reconstructive approach, the study investigated how teachersâ€™ beliefs and the way teachers address the complexity of sustainability issues relate to each other. Based on 17 narrative interviews with secondary school teachers in Germany, the study reveals patterns of how teachers address the complexity of sustainability issues and how these patterns become visible in the way teachers construct the interconnectedness of the world and in their understanding of teaching and learning. Three abstracted ways were reconstructed from the empirical material: (1) promoting an authentic perspective in teacher-led approaches, (2) focusing on multiple perspectives in fact-based approaches and (3) emphasising reflexivity in addition to multiple perspectives on global issues in student-centred approaches. The article discusses the findings in terms of their relevance to current knowledge about studentsâ€™ learning processes. #complexity #teaching #educationforsustainabledevelopment #authenticity #reflexivity #values #SDG4 https://lnkd.in/gR8e7839
